The mathematical foundations of quantum theory have been a source of controversy for more than a century. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. Our approach is based on the observation that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators has a monoidal structure, and that the category of Hilbert spaces and adjointable operators has a dual monoidal structure. We use these structures to define a notion of functor between categories of states, and to prove that the category of Hilbert spaces and adjointable operators has a full and faithful subcategory of continuous states, which is closed under retracts and has a dual. This subcategory is equivalent to the category of continuous states, and hence the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators, and thus quantum theory, is categorical.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two species of myxozoans, which represent the most distant members of the group. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister group to the more complex group of animals that includes the parasitic group, the Ctenophora, and the free-living group, the Cnidaria. Our analyses also reveal that myxozoans are one of the most reduced animal groups, with a small genome and a reduced gene content. This extreme reduction in gene content is likely to have occurred during the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 70%. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the variability of maize yields will increase substantially under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This higher variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the world’s major maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports. This will increase the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. This is an urgent and important message for the global community.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition for seven species of African LMH, and found that the extent of dietary overlap was greater between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption than within either grazers or browsers. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings highlight the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of LMH in ecosystems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. Our results highlight the need for a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and intriguing questions in science. The solar system is thought to have formed from the aggregation of interstellar dust particles. However, the age of the solar system is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. Our results indicate that the solar system formed within the last 4.6 Ga.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. This study provides a comprehensive reconstruction of the evolution of the global fishing fleet and its impact on the global fisheries. It is the first to disaggregate the data into artisanal and industrial sectors, and to estimate the engine power of the fleet. The results are important for understanding the impact of the global fishing fleet on the global fisheries and the environment. The ability to provide resources to offspring is a defining characteristic of animals and is thought to be a major factor in the success of domestication. Here, we show that the practice of allonursing, in which a female provides resources to her offspring before they are born, is the most effective way to increase reproductive output. This is a major finding because it suggests that the increase in reproductive output in domestic animals is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather an increase in the mother’s metabolic power. This finding has implications for the evolution of animal behavior and the origins of domestication. (Less)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is fatal within a few years after onset, and no treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, controlling the blood flow, and controlling the clotting of the blood. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell that is constantly receiving information from the rest of the body and must integrate this information to control the functions of the blood vessels. This paper describes the design of the communication network between the endothelial cells and the nature of the communication network. The communication network is found to be highly efficient in the transmission of information between the cells. The design of the communication network is found to be effective in the control of the functions of the blood vessels.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, particularly for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API is a resource that can be used to monitor the pandemic, to augment traditional public health reporting, and to empower research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to a wide range of stakeholders.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being elucidated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the environment. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host’s diet, and the composition of the microbiome can be used to assess the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host’s lifestyle, and the microbiome can be used to predict the host’s diet and exercise habits. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host’s health, and the microbiome can be used to predict the host’s health. This paper provides evidence that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used to treat human disease.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait associated with a low social competitiveness, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness of high-anxious individuals is associated with a reduced probability to become dominant and that this is mediated by reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic approaches. (Show more)

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design of complex structures with specific and extreme responses is still challenging. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases that seamlessly collaborate to produce complex and extreme responses. The synthesized structures are digitally designed and manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are then assembled into architectures to achieve highly complex and navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture other complex structures with specific responses. The strategy can be applied to design and manufacture a wide range of mechanical devices for various applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of aging. The hemoglobin system is controlled by a complex network of factors. Here we show that one of these factors, insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), is expressed in human erythroid tissues and can affect the hemoglobin profile of human erythroblasts.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, sensitized cancer cells to ferroptosis. In preclinical models, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction showed promise for the treatment of cancer. These findings provide a basis for the development of new cancer therapies. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) is the most common treatment for hypertension. However, the mechanisms of LCCBs in the regulation of vascular remodeling are not well understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI Ca2+ channels, which are up-regulated in hypertension. Our findings provide a mechanism for the association of LCCBs with cardiovascular disease and suggest that LCCBs should be used with caution in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet succeeded in reversing the decline of older forest-associated bird species. The NWFP has halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has not yet been sufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area has stabilized, but declined in two ecoregions, and early-seral bird populations declined. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. The NWFP is a model for how science can inform policy, and we hope that this study will contribute to the ongoing efforts to improve forest management in the Pacific Northwest.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work is a step forward in the development of new antibiotics. (Abridged)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the number of parameters increases exponentially with the depth of the network. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that is easier to train and apply. The proposed architecture is based on a simple set of operations that can be easily implemented and trained. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful in many image-processing problems. The code for the proposed architecture is available at https://github.com/yannickdelange/simple_net.

The evolution of the African Rift System and the formation of Lake Malawi have been linked to the development of the East African interior monsoon, which is a key component of the African monsoon system. However, the timing and magnitude of the African monsoon have been difficult to assess, in part because of the lack of a continuous, high-resolution record of lake level. Here we present a continuous, 1.3-My record of lake level from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We show that the African monsoon was highly variable in the past, and that the monsoon was drier than today during the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, and that the monsoon was wetter during the Late Pleistocene. These results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the African monsoon system.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-shift the circadian clock, and reduce sleep quality. Here we show that this practice also reduces the amount of sleep, increases the time to fall asleep, and reduces the amount of sleep that is actually obtained. These effects are likely to have important consequences for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still to be determined. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be exacerbated by the loss of Treg cells. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its function is not limited to the development of tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is linked to the evolution of plants, and that the evolution of their diet was key to the diversification of beetles.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid and effective vaccine and therapeutic development. However, the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the efficacy of existing vaccines and therapeutics. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to improve the neutralizing activity of human antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against the Alpha, Beta, and Gamma variants but not the Delta variant. Our approach can be used to improve the neutralizing activity of existing antibodies and potentially develop new ones. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules, such as monoclonal antibodies, and may have applications in the development of vaccines and therapeutics for other pathogens.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance cumulative cultural evolution. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and cumulative cultural evolution. These results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance cumulative cultural evolution. Our results also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. This work is important for understanding the evolution of technology in human societies.

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for Alzheimer’s disease. These data put APOE central to Alzheimer’s disease pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify Alzheimer’s disease risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core. This finding provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox, which has been a long-standing problem in geophysics.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well established, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are key features of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. This has led to the hypothesis that language processing is a signature cognitive function of the human mind. Here, we test this hypothesis by linking the most powerful deep learning models in natural language processing to data from neuroimaging studies of language processing. We find that these models capture the vast majority of the neural variance associated with processing language, suggesting that they capture fundamental aspects of the underlying computations. These results provide computational evidence for the special nature of language processing in the human mind. They also provide a promising approach for future studies of the neural basis of language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear whether DL is a special case of a more general class of problems, or whether it is fundamentally different. We address this question by studying the stability of neural networks. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a neural network. This result implies a classification theory describing conditions under which stable neural networks can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the failure of science communication. The pandemic’s origins are a matter of intense debate, and the scientific community is split on the issue. However, the debate is often framed as a clash between “fact-based science” and “conspiracy theories.” This framing is misleading, as the scientific community is just as split on the question of the pandemic’s origins. This article is a contribution to the discussion on the origins of the pandemic. It is also a plea for more science communication that is based on science rather than on political agendas.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still a major public health problem in the developing world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and is now a small, simple bacterium. In contrast, the pathogen associated with the rare, but severe, diffuse form of leprosy, known as lepromatous leprosy, is a large, complex bacterium that is still able to cause disease. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, a leprosy bacterium that is common in Mexico, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved, and that they are still able to cause disease.

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain can be understood in the scaling limit of the time evolution. This is achieved by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain. Our work provides a powerful tool for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and caused severe economic damage. The only available vaccines are not 100% effective, and the pandemic is not yet under control. Therefore, a vaccine with a high degree of safety and efficacy is urgently needed. Here, we describe a vaccine that is highly attenuated and, therefore, safe. This vaccine is also easy to manufacture on a large scale, which is essential for mass vaccination programs. The vaccine is also easy to manufacture on a large scale, which is essential for mass vaccination programs.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague in Europe is poorly understood. Here, we develop a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a new perspective on the history of plague in Europe. It also has implications for the spread of plague in the 21st century.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. The study of brain evolution is hampered by the lack of data on the number of neurons in ancient brains. Here, we use the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuron numbers in amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies have shown that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others have shown that it is an oncogene. Here, we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator that promotes the switch from oxidative phosphorylation to aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1 also promotes invasiveness of these cells. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton. ADF is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell differentiation. ADF is also involved in the regulation of the cell cycle, and its activity is regulated by the cytoskeleton. Here, we show that the mechanical state of the filament network can have a profound effect on ADF activity. We show that the mechanical state of the filament network can have a profound effect on ADF activity. We show that the mechanical state of the filament network can have a profound effect on ADF activity.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island has a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a demographic growth, but that the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It is also a reminder that the history of Madagascar is not only the history of Madagascar, but also the history of the Indian Ocean. This is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which is well established in laboratory experiments but is controversial in real-world settings. Our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact in person. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social media platforms, and for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to impact the rate of protein synthesis. However, the impact of mRNA modifications on the rate of translation has not been studied in a reconstituted translation system. Here, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNAs can modestly alter the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNAs can have a modest impact on the rate of translation. This study provides a foundation for future studies on the impact of mRNA modifications on the rate of translation. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including better social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders, and the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is associated with positive change over time. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. This study provides evidence for the importance of a sense of worthwhile living in older age.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a central theme in the study of evolution in the water. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold, and the temperature of the nasal cavity is an important factor in the course of the disease. We show that the rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the temperature of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. This is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense the environment and regulate its virulence. This is an example of how bacteria can use their surface adhesins for sensing and regulation of their own activity.

The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of peer-reviewed studies that evaluates the presence of particularly toxic agricultural insecticides in surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the global pesticide problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The origin of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is still unknown, but it is clear that humans are not the only species susceptible to infection. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our findings highlight the need for continued surveillance of wildlife populations to better understand the potential for spillover events and the potential for animal reservoirs to act as a source of new variants. This information is critical for developing effective public health strategies and mitigating the risk of future outbreaks.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the future of the planet. The paper examines the problems associated with building large dams in developing countries and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. It also examines the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global public health crisis. The immune system is increasingly recognized as a critical player in AD, but the mechanisms by which it contributes to the disease are not well understood. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the production of a neuron-specific inflammatory response. This response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may therefore represent a critical therapeutic target for the treatment of AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for understanding the role of this species in the development of agriculture and animal husbandry. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is to be found in the Hellenistic period at the site of Maresha, Israel. The results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are not known for most proteins. However, the folding of some proteins is of special interest because of their large size, their importance in disease, or their potential for use in a therapeutic application. Here, we describe the folding of a large protein, the maltose binding protein. We show that the folding of this protein proceeds in distinct steps, and we identify the intermediates in the folding process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the concentration of Np4 and the extent to which it affects gene expression remain unclear. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is responsible for removing the cap from mRNA, also plays a critical role in the decapping of Np4-capped transcripts. Our results suggest that the concentration of Np4 is controlled by a feedback mechanism in which the cellular response to stress is used to regulate the concentration of RppH, which in turn controls the rate at which Np4-capped RNAs are degraded. This mechanism could be used to reprogram gene expression in response to stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the pathogenesis of the disease. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and immune homeostasis during sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a potential strategy for the treatment of sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We highlight that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to a state of constant activity. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, and neural networks. In this paper, we introduce a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe the connection between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, it is not a perfect insulator, and its electronic properties can be modified by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering, and the electronic properties can be tuned by strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a new approach to explore the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of diamond science and technology.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a rapidly evolving field. The study of the antifungal activity of peptides is a relatively new area of research. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, the 36-residue NCR044, and its antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate the potential of this peptide as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the female reproductive tract makes a contribution to the development of the offspring. However, the extent of this contribution is largely unknown. Here, we show that the female reproductive tract makes a substantial contribution to the development of the offspring. We also show that the male–female interface is dynamic, and the female contribution to the offspring is dependent on the duration of the interaction. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of the male–female interface.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by interacting with glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα). Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This is the first time that the conversion of single molecule kon to bulk phase kon has been demonstrated. The results are important for understanding the role of force in the regulation of VWF. They also provide a method for measuring the kon and koff values of biomolecules. This method can be used to study the role of force in the regulation of VWF.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that is intimately involved in human health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered efforts to understand the impact of viruses on human health. This study addresses this gap, and provides a resource for the community to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is able to simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to investigate ACI processes. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI community.

The temperature history of the early Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and early evolution of life. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is lower than the average surface temperature of the present, but the reliability of this estimate has been questioned. Here, we use the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to estimate the paleotemperature of ancient organisms. Our results suggest that the surface temperature of the early Earth decreased over time, consistent with previous estimates. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis that the origin of life was preceded by the evolution of the necessary biochemical machinery, and it provides a new approach for estimating the temperature history of the early Earth.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We hypothesized that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide, and there is no cure for the disease. The Plasmodium parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle, and the invasion process is the start of the disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, and this interaction alters the physical properties of the RBC. This change in the physical properties of the RBC primes the cell for invasion, and we propose that this is a major mechanism by which the parasite causes disease.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, it is not a perfect insulator, and its electronic properties can be modified by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly by applying tensile strain. This work offers opportunities for tailoring the electronic properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of diamond science.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain’s processing of language is often described in terms of a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but suddenly decreases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a left-corner parser and provides initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is a fundamental step in the construction of meaning.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in many important biological processes, including development and cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the two forms of Axin. This subtle feature may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

Obesity is a major public health problem, and the mechanisms that govern overeating are not well understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces rapid vigorous eating in sated mice. This effect is blocked by lesions of the dopamine system, suggesting that it is a downstream circuit. We further show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, but rather in the promotion of overeating. This circuit may be a target for the treatment of obesity.

Nitrogen is a key resource for plant growth and productivity, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a critical tool for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to engineer a sustainable nitrogen cycle in agriculture. This work also represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in the environment, where the bacteria would be prevented from interaction with nontarget organisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in the environment.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate, and the causes of this deforestation are not well understood. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by providing early alerts about deforestation to communities and incentivizing them to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the experiment. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the difficulty of measuring deforestation in the absence of deforestation alerts. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their senses to perceive the world and to interact with it. The sense of hearing is particularly important for animals that live in complex and noisy environments. The ears of animals are usually part of their bodies, but some animals, such as spiders, can hear without being part of the body. Here, we show that the web of a spider acts as an acoustic antenna and that the spider can hear without a body. This is a unique example of outsourcing hearing to an external medium. We discuss the advantages of this strategy for the spider and for the study of acoustic sensing in animals. We also discuss the potential applications of this technology for acoustic flow detection and manipulation. This work provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing in animals.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. Our results indicate that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. Aerosols affect the hydrologic cycle, contributing to water and food security. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results highlight the importance of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources for global health and climate.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. Vaccine development has been rapid, and several vaccines are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. Here we report a recombinant protein vaccine that is well-established, proven, and suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing. This vaccine contains an engineered variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) that exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, high-yield manufacturability, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD may provide a cost-effective, accessible, and manufacturable vaccine for global access to COVID-19 vaccines. (Less)

The role of the ALK/ALKALS receptor–ligand pair in the development of neural crest-derived tissues is unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALS regulate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK, which are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We further show that loss of ALKALS causes iridophore loss in zebrafish larvae and that loss-of-function alleles are lethal. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALKALS in neural crest development.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a key event in the history of the genus Yersinia. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical period for the development of the disease. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic in the 4th century CE persisted for millennia, with rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague, which is critical for understanding the origins of this disease. (Less)

This work examined the role of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States.

The management of agricultural systems has a profound impact on the quantity and quality of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural soils. In this study, we show that the management of annual cropping systems on a Midwestern Mollisol can be optimized to increase SOC storage and the quality of SOC. We found that the addition of manure and the integration of legumes into annual cropping systems increased the quantity of soil organic matter, but did not increase the quality of SOC. In contrast, rotational grazing of pastures increased the quality of SOC, as well as the quantity of SOC and the quality of soil organic matter. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in the fight against climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a valuable resource for the global scientific community and the public. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of the red pigment, and show that the same three enzymatic activities are also present in the red nectar of hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. This work provides evidence for convergent evolution of a key trait in two different plant species, suggesting that the red pigment is a highly favored trait and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also demonstrates that the red color of nectar is not a unique cue for pollinators, but rather a general signal of the presence of alkaloids. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had skull deformations that were likely caused by cranial deformation. We show that these women had a genetic ancestry that was unexpected for a group of women living in Europe at that time. In addition, we show that the genetic history of the group is very complex, and that the women had a high degree of admixture from different parts of Europe. Our results indicate that the genetic history of Europe during the Migration Period was more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future bat coronavirus-related epidemics. This article is protected by

The global pandemic of COVID-19 has highlighted the need for rapid, accurate, and scalable pathogen surveillance. Here, we demonstrate the feasibility of using next-generation sequencing (NGS) to rapidly identify pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a larger national outbreak. Pathogen-agnostic NGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to rapidly identify pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings.

The human genome is replicated in a highly coordinated and complex process. The lagging strand of the genome is replicated by a single DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) that is responsible for synthesizing the Okazaki fragments. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical to the process of lagging strand replication. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic studies that reveal that the human pol δ holoenzyme is unusually stable. This stability is not required for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments but is necessary for the rapid dissociation of pol δ from the PCNA sliding clamp.

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be copied by RNA polymerases, but the properties of these enzymes are not well understood. Here, we report the results of an in vitro evolution experiment that led to the creation of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This polymerase can also replicate RNA, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the creation of an in vitro RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a severe disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is still in the stage of trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting interleukin 6, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected to provide a new treatment option for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a highly toxic metal. The existence of a fungal metal homeostasis system is well established, but the role of natural products in this process has not been explored. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is involved in copper homeostasis in Aspergillus fumigatus, and that the secreted isocyanide products of this gene cluster have antimicrobial properties. The existence of this system in other filamentous fungi suggests a previously unknown role for eukaryotic natural products in mediating interactions with competing microbes. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the role of fungal natural products in metal homeostasis and the evolution of interactions with microbes. (Show more)

The origin of the abundant silica on Mars is a key question in understanding the history of the planet. The presence of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is consistent with the hypothesis that the silica is of magmatic origin. The silica is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals, indicating that it precipitated from aqueous solutions.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the world’s most important carbon sinks. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to the warming climate, and that this change is already affecting the functioning of forests. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, and that these cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis and that the development of Th17 cells may be a therapeutic target in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly and easily generate induced astrocytes from living ALS patients. This will enable the study of the disease in a disease model that is easily expandable and amenable to high-throughput drug screening. This will accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of the tick Ixodes scapularis, which influences the ability of the pathogen to colonize the vector. We demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by altering the composition of the tick gut microbiome and by altering the composition of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical obstacle for the colonization of the pathogen. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of arthropod vectors and may lead to the development of novel strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most iconic and enigmatic stories in evolution. The discovery of a new group of early pygostylians adds to our understanding of the origin of the modern avian body plan. This group, Jinguofortis, is an important addition to the early history of birds because it preserves a mosaic of plesiomorphic and derived features. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis. The discovery of Jinguofortis also highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. (Less)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is not always easy to understand the role of individual processes. Here, we show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

The evolution of color in animals is one of the most striking features of the animal kingdom. In this study, we show that the occurrence of high biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Additionally, we found that these BBSs are most similar to human glycoprotein alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our findings provide a molecular basis for the evolution of chlorosis in anurans and a new function for a serpin. These results are of interest to the general public and the scientific community.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer cells are often exposed to hypoxia, which is associated with poor prognosis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces breast cancer cells to express a breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype, which is associated with increased expression of NANOG, a factor that is essential for embryonic stem cell pluripotency. We also show that NANOG expression is regulated by hypoxia and HIF-1α, and that this regulation is dependent on ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a key innovation, and the source of the parchment has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This process may have been used to produce the first pocket Bibles. (Less)

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. Understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depends on an accurate and precise age model. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.
