The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis, which is disrupted in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. Here, we demonstrate that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in the viral spike protein, and it is thought to increase the transmissibility of the virus. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the D614G and G614 spike proteins and show that the G614 mutant spike is more open and flexible, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion with the viral membrane. These results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) to the case of repeated games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are the starting point for the study of chemical reactions, chemical bonding, and chemical reactions. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. This work provides a predictive and explicative power of chemical properties under pressure. It also provides a new perspective on the chemical behavior of the elements. This work is a first step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can affect the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire regimes are highly uncertain, and the effects of human ignitions are poorly understood. Here, we show that human ignitions can reduce the effects of climate change on the global carbon cycle. This is especially true under lower emission scenarios, which are more likely to be realized. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions in shaping the future fire regime and the potential for climate–fire feedbacks to mitigate global warming.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, at a specific time of day. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting metabolites to maintain a stable symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning rhythm is established only after the squid has reached sexual maturity, suggesting that it is a critical factor in the establishment of the symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, in which the host provides a single nutrient at a specific time of day, and the symbiont uses this nutrient to maintain a stable symbiosis. This strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. This method draws on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward the goal of automated text analysis for social good.

The second plague pandemic, which began in the 14th century, is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague, which is likely to be replicated in other infectious disease outbreaks. It also has implications for the spread of other pathogens in the past and in the future.

Asteroids are the most likely candidates for the mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America. We provide evidence that the disease is caused by a densovirus. The virus is transmitted by the sea stars themselves, and the disease is associated with increased viral load. The virus has been present on the Pacific Coast for at least 72 y, and it is likely that it has been present on other coasts for a similar period. This is the first report of a densovirus causing mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of blood cancer, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor, which is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of other diseases. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island has a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a demographic growth, and that the settlement was not uniform across the island. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It is also a reminder that the history of Madagascar is not only the history of Madagascar, but also the history of the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that is both “noncoding” and regulatory.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of antibody-based therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work is also timely, as the emergence of the Delta and Omicron variants has necessitated the development of new antibody-based therapeutics.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting Crop Condition Index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be used to monitor the status of other agricultural commodities, and can be extended to other types of data, such as social media, to improve the quality of the information available to farmers and policymakers.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the ability of neurons to store information in their conductances. This mechanism is adaptive, context-sensitive, and sensitive to serial order. We show that this mechanism can support the binding of linguistic features over time, and that it can be used to integrate information over short and long time periods. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that is based on the ability of neurons to store information in their conductances. It is a step toward a more complete understanding of the neural basis of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The origin of plastids and the evolution of their genomes are central questions in the origin of life. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major step in the evolution of plastids, and the molecular signature of this transition is unknown. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to the extent of functional reduction, and that the establishment of the obligate parasitic lifestyle is linked to the loss of photosynthesis. These findings provide a molecular framework for the study of the origin of plastids and their genomes. They also provide a model for the origin of the molecular signature of the origin of life.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of multiyear droughts in southwestern South Africa is assessed using a high-resolution large ensemble. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of improving the understanding of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of extreme droughts in SSA. This is a key step in the development of drought risk management strategies.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, which was formed in the aftermath of the nuclear explosion, provides a unique link between the formation of the material and the date of the explosion.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is accomplished by chlorophyll, a molecule that is modified in a variety of ways. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll molecule is a key step in the biosynthesis of the photosynthetic pigments. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here, we show that the formation of the fifth ring of chlorophyll is catalyzed by three different enzymes, which we term O2-dependent, O2-sensitive, and O2-insensitive, respectively.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the development of cell-type–specific ASK1 inhibitors for the treatment of neuroinflammation. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased over the past two decades, and that this increase is likely due to human activities. This finding is important because it suggests that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a potential target for drug development. (Show more)
This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights the potential for more positive content.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the STIM1 Ca2+ sensor that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including congenital bleeding diathesis and tubular myopathy. We also identify mutations in the ORAI1 pore-forming protein that result in congenital bleeding diathesis and miosis. These data expand our understanding of the molecular basis of store-operated Ca2+ entry, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates, which is in turn dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active transport. These results provide a foundation for future studies of the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases.

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is believed to be a key factor in the absence of viral diseases in bats. However, the immune system of bats is not completely immune privileged, and bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. Here, we identified a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential explanation for the absence of viral diseases in bats. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key regulator of cell growth. In this study, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and develop a strategy to exploit it. We identify a small molecule that inhibits both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2, and show that it blocks tumor growth in a mouse model of colon cancer. We also show that this strategy is effective in B-cell lines, but uniquely effective in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a disease of the same type. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and a strategy to exploit it. This work has implications for the treatment of cancer, and for the study of one-carbon metabolism.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease that affects motor neurons, leading to progressive muscle weakness and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic mutations leading to different clinical phenotypes. Here, we show that the proteins that are colocalized with mutant superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and FUS in motor neurons are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies that contain these proteins are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners, suggesting that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is a general phenomenon. This metastable state of the inclusion bodies may be a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, leading to the formation of inclusions. Our results suggest that the pathogenesis of ALS is more complex than previously thought. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The photonic crystal devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal devices are expected to be scalable to larger dimensions. This work is expected to have a broad impact on the field of atom optics, and the photonic crystal devices are expected to be scalable to larger dimensions. This work is expected to have a broad impact on the field of atom optics.

The Cretaceous is a critical time in the history of life, with the origin of many major groups. The origin of the flowering plants is a major event in the Cretaceous story, but the details of this origin are poorly understood. Here we present a detailed study of a previously poorly understood plant from the early Cretaceous of Spain. This study provides a major advance in our understanding of the origin of the flowering plants.

The study of ancient viruses is important for our understanding of the evolution of viruses and the origin of new viral lineages. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences, which are phylogenetically related to the most recent common ancestor of all B19V. We also provide evidence for a recombination event that formed the B19V genotype 2. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is a well-known phenomenon, but the causes are still debated. In this paper, we show that the acceleration is consistent with a warming climate, and that the rate of sea level rise is increasing in lockstep with the rate of warming. This is a significant contribution to the ongoing debate.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not a new phenomenon, but one that has been ongoing for several decades. If this trend continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this defining species. This integrated approach offers a powerful tool for the study of enzyme mechanisms, providing a means to understand the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites and the chemical reactions that occur there.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) remains a severe and deadly disease, with a high case fatality rate. There is an urgent need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to patients, healthcare workers, and the wider community.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, at a specific time of day. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting metabolites to maintain a stable symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning rhythm is established only after the squid has colonized a new host, suggesting that it is a critical component of the maturation process. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, in which the host provides a single nutrient at a specific time of day, and the symbiont uses this nutrient to maintain a stable symbiosis. This strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes.

This paper describes a series of experiments that tested the impact of a brief, online intervention on teachers’ mindsets about discipline. The intervention was designed to encourage teachers to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. The intervention was evaluated in three districts, in three states, and in three school systems. The intervention halved year-long student suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention. This paper describes a scalable, evidence-based approach to reducing suspension rates. It is a promising step toward reducing the racial achievement gap.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of how DNA alkylation affects the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can all induce transcriptional stalling, and the stalling profiles are dependent on the position of the EtdT lesion on the DNA template. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. It also provides a foundation for the development of novel strategies for the prevention of mutagenesis and cancer caused by DNA alkylation. This article is protected by copyright. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe disease in humans. To understand the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus’s spike (S) glycoproteins. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and is a major contributor to the global obesity epidemic. The food choices people make are a key determinant of the environmental and health impacts of the food system. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering environment can have a significant impact on meal selection behavior. This has important implications for the environment and population health. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering environments is a simple and effective way to promote more sustainable diets and improve population health. This approach could be easily implemented in a wide range of settings. We hope that our findings will encourage further research and practical implementation of this approach.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the cell surface proteome is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line expressing oncogenes, and show how the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion. We find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a coordinated fashion, and that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common biological themes. This study provides a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggests possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the cell surface in cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune suppression and evasion. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of novel therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex, which in turn contributes to the development of edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe the problem and its solution. The solution is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is a fundamental change in the way that we think about inference in the era of big data.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. Although many attempts have been made to generate ECs from pluripotent stem cells and nonvascular cells, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce vascular ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells. Our study provides a promising approach for the generation of vascular ECs and the development of vascular networks for the treatment of vascular disorders. This study also provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders. This study also provides a new strategy for the treatment of vascular disorders.

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases ALK and LTK has opened up a new field of research. In this study, we show that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophores, which are a type of chromatophore. We also show that the zebrafish augmentor ligands are essential for the development of the eye and the skin. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and LTK and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate LTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for future studies on the role of these ligands in human diseases.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is decreased in β-cells of diabetic mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Mechanistically, STING is required for β-cell function, and its nuclear localization is lost in STING-deficient β-cells. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza, and their pandemic potential is a major concern. The packaging of the viral genome is essential for the production of infectious virions, but the molecular details of the packaging process remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results provide insights into the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses and may help in the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process involving multiple factors. In this study, we identified a critical role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the regulation of disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural and important part of many ecosystems, but they can also be destructive and costly. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. This work highlights the importance of understanding the role of human activities in driving changes in fire regimes.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that senses natural repellents, and demonstrated that this channel is a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod. This study provides a new approach to the development of natural repellents and the control of insect pests. It also helps to understand the molecular mechanism of the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This process is a key factor in the early stages of bleaching and may ultimately help us to understand the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing world.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of a tumor suppressor, which leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, results in the loss of the intestinal barrier. We also show that the loss of the tumor suppressor leads to the loss of the microbiome, which in turn leads to the loss of the tumor suppressor. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium. This work also provides a model for studying the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. This work also provides a model for studying the role of the microbiome in host–microbe interactions. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the primary treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is a major determinant of survival. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated deglaciation of the Southern Hemisphere is a key question in the history of the last ice age. Here we show that the start of this period was linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in the Southern Hemisphere climate system. This finding provides a new perspective on the timing of the start of the last ice age, and it has implications for the timing of the next ice age.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels, and that fishing pressure is most intense in rivers where potential impacts on biodiversity are highest. Our analysis highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need to protect these ecosystems from the impacts of human activities. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of freshwater fisheries, and to identify regions where river ecosystems are most vulnerable to fishing pressure. This analysis underscores the need to include inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are revealed by hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, which is the key to achieve high energy density and durable aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous batteries.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult Caenorhabditis elegans nervous system that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathways known to mediate regeneration in the adult Drosophila and mammalian nervous systems. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is driven by sensory activity, calcium, and cAMP. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for the discovery of novel mechanisms that regulate the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we use a population of wild flowers to map the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions that are completely devoid of recombination. This pattern is reminiscent of that observed in yeast and mice, suggesting that recombination initiation in eukaryotes may have a common origin.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has revolutionized our understanding of the human brain. However, the RSN is only a small fraction of total brain activity, and its functional significance is not fully understood. Here, we show that metabolic imaging can provide a direct measure of the dominant RSN in healthy subjects, and that this RSN is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant RSN is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network deactivation was observed in early PD, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain, and its potential implications for the study of brain function and disease are discussed.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). However, the existence of other 5′ modifications has been controversial. Here, we show that the 5′ end of some nuclear and mitochondrial mRNAs are modified with nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+), a molecule that is a key component of the NAD+ metabolic pathway. We demonstrate that NAD+ is produced cotranscriptionally and that it is associated with the 5′ end of subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial mRNAs. Our results suggest that NAD+ may play a role in regulating the stability and translation of specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the phenomenon of maintaining beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications for several years after the discontinuation of intensive therapy. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here, we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes persist for several years after discontinuation of intensive therapy. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and is associated with poor prognosis. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disease, and the mechanisms involved in its development are still poorly understood. In this study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for studying the evolution of fruit flavor, and the study of its volatile constituents has been a major focus of research. The biosynthesis of many of these volatiles is not known, and the study of the underlying genes is a major goal of research. Here, we report the identification of a gene that is essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a unique class of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. Here we show that the impacts of these two factors are not independent of each other. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changed as temperatures shifted from ambient conditions. This change in the relationship was driven by two processes. First, more diverse communities were more likely to contain species with thermal traits that enabled them to maintain ecosystem functioning. Second, the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increased at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for predicting the impacts of climate change on the functioning of Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for navigation, are organized separately from other cell types, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its relation to navigation. They also suggest that the organization of the MEC is more complex than previously thought. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the functional organization of the MEC. (Less)

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is involved in the regulation of flowering in a parasitic plant. This is an important finding, as it illustrates that the flowering signal FT is not only involved in the regulation of flowering in the host, but also in the regulation of flowering in the parasite. This study also illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro–striato–nigral loop form a specialized system that is disrupted in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. Within this system, we identify a unique formation of striosomal neurons that project to dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clusters of cells likely represent specialized integrative units within the system. Given the role of striosomes in mood and motivation, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a detailed view of the dopamine system in the brain and its relationship to nigral cell bodies. It also provides a model for the study of the organization of the brain.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and that its deletion in mice results in a reduction in the content of Ca2+ stores in these cells. This, in turn, leads to a reduction in the number of Ca2+ sparks, which are the events that occur in the plasma membrane of the cardiomyocyte and are essential for the generation of the electrical impulse. These results reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its role in plant physiology has been debated. In this study, we show that Si can enhance the resistance of rice against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote the accumulation of Si in rice, and that this interaction may be important for the resistance of rice to insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant physiology and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest control. (Abridged)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the ability of neurons to store information in their conductances. This mechanism is adaptive and can be accessed directly without the need for cued retrieval. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based biotechnologies. The delivery of functional biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we demonstrate the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are critical design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of plant-based biotechnologies.

Nutrient inputs to coastal ecosystems are a major threat to the health of lakes and oceans worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient inputs to lakes come from small tributaries, which are often overlooked in efforts to reduce nutrient pollution. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in areas where dams have altered the natural hydrology of the watershed. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combinations of initial conditions that led to the observed universe are biased toward states that extremize the probability of the observed state. Our results suggest that the same mechanism may be at work in the design of chemical networks.

This study offers a mechanistic understanding of the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain. It shows that the effects of these antibodies on the brain are not limited to the receptor, but also extend to the network level. This study also offers a potential explanation for the paroxysmal nature of the effects of these antibodies. Finally, this study offers a potential explanation for the diversity of effects of these antibodies, as well as the effects of other antibodies, on the brain.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. Understanding the history of abrupt warming events is therefore of utmost importance to assess the potential impacts of ongoing anthropogenic warming. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was accompanied by a perturbation of the carbon cycle, which is of relevance for the current warming.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the primary tool used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification appears to be most effective in reducing deforestation in oil palm plantations that are already degraded and contain little residual forest. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the regulation of many cellular processes, including the trafficking of the vacuole and the recycling of endosomes. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that binds to the exocyst complex and inhibits exocytosis. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study in developmental biology. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In contrast, many fish have multiple alleles at a sex determination locus, resulting in multiple genotypic sexes. Here we show that the multiple genotypic sexes of M. mbenjii can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, which can be further modified by introgression of a newly acquired sex determination allele. These results suggest that the maintenance of multiple genotypic sexes can produce a diversity of phenotypes, which can be modified by introgression. This provides a context for understanding the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of toxic species that are generated by the photoreceptor cells. In this study, we show that the levels of iron in the retina, as reflected in the transferrin receptor, impact the levels of bisretinoids, a class of toxic species that are generated by the oxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium. We also show that the levels of iron in the retina impact the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E, which is a major contributor to the photodamage of the retina. These findings have implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and other retinal diseases. (Show more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of new prey types is a key driver of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of new prey types is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a key driver of the diversification of the animal kingdom.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolutionary biology. The study of the evolution of the human hand is complicated by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, was present ∼1.42 Mya in an East African hominin from Kaitio, West Turkana, Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. Here we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target of cancer, and that targeting SHMT is a promising strategy for cancer therapy. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it is effective in cancer cell lines, but not in normal cells. This suggests that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer therapy, and that it may be possible to develop a cancer-specific SHMT inhibitor.

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized, despite a growing body of literature showing that having access to forests can improve people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. In this study, we show that deforestation over a 5-y period (2008–2013) led to a reduction in household fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, we found that forest fragmentation over the survey period led to an increase in consumption of these foods and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study finds a causal link between deforestation and people’s dietary quality, and the results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a modeling approach to test causal hypotheses in the social sciences. We believe that this study will be of interest to researchers in the social sciences, particularly those working in the area of environmental and resource economics.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show here that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the largest sauropods, the brachiosaurids, had the longest foraging trails. Our findings have implications for the design of farm machinery and the evolution of sauropod locomotion. (Abridged)
